description.narrative: By 2022, MoHS and other partners at national and sub-national level, including non-state actors, have improved capacity to integrate HIV testing and treatment interventions for young children and key adolescent populations into essential health service delivery approaches sustainably at scale, which contributes to Adolescent Health And Nutrition, Hiv Prevention, Operations Support To Programme Delivery, Treatment And Care Of Children Living With Hiv. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Evaluations, Research And Data, Fostering Innovation And Use Of New Technologies, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2022, more children under 5 and women of reproductive age equitably access and utilize evidence-based health, HIV & nutrition interventions, including adoption of key behaviours, especially among vulnerable populations in most deprived states/regions, conflict-affected and peri-urban areas (Goal Area 1 UNICEF Strategic Framework 2018-2021)

participating-org.narrative: DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH SCHOOL HEALTH DIVISION
DPH HIV AIDS DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH

sector.narrative: HIV - Emergency preparedness and response including Post exposure prophylaxis and risk informed conflict sensitive HIV programming

HIV health and community system strengthening to improve access and adherence
HIV testing including self testing and counselling in adolescents
Support Policy and guidance developments and address barriers to accessing HIV services by adolescents including gender mainstreaming

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By 2022, MoHS and other partners at national and sub-national level, including non-state actors, have improved capacity to integrate HIV testing and treatment interventions for young children and key adolescent populations into essential health service delivery approaches sustainably at scale

description.narrative: COVID-19 pandemic disrupted HIV services especially outreach prevention and testing, client visits at facilities, linkage, referral and viral-load testing due to travel restrictions, lockdown, transport interruption. To mitigate the impact of COVID-19, Interim Guidance has been developed in March and implemented since early April 2020 considering modified approach and innovative ways. Government also improved policy and data management systems in HIV prevention and care programmes. Partners' capacities were strengthened, and communities are mobilized to increase access for HIV prevention, treatment and care services for adolescent key population, pregnant women and children living with HIV. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:30/07/2020

title.narrative: Myanmar is implementing three high-impact gender-responsive adolescent HIV prevention interventions

baseline.value: 1 (implementing one high-impact gender-responsive adolescent HIV prevention intervention)

title.narrative: National HIV Strategy and Plans for care and treatment that are aligned to the most recent WHO child and adolescent recommendations for care and treatment and included includes targets for children and adolescents

baseline.value: 2 (National strategy and plans are not aligned to most recent WHO recommendations)

target.value: 2022:3 (National strategy and plans have been aligned to the most recent WHO recommendations)

actual.value: 2019:3 (National strategy and plans have been aligned to the most recent WHO recommendations)

title.narrative: Existence of age- and sex-disaggregated data on HIV testing and counselling among adolescents 15 -19 years and by sex
